bibl.title: Letter from Robert F. Woodward to Philip Showalter Hench, September 8, 1954

div1.p: Woodward writes about a French delegation preparing a resolution to propose that a French doctor originally theorized that mosquitoes transmitted yellow fever. In the interest of Cuban and American relations, Woodward wants Hench to provide details on Finlay's contributions.

div1.head: Letter from Robert F. Woodward to Philip Showalter Hench, September 8, 1954
div1.opener:
ADDRESS OFFICIAL COMMUNICATIONS TO
THE SECRETARY OF STATE
WASHINGTON 25, D. C.
[unclear]
DEPARTMENT OF STATE
WASHINGTON
In reply refer to:
ARA
September 8, 1954
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I have just received a letter from the American Embassy at
Habana concerning the keen interest of the Cuban Government and
medical fraternity in defending and substantiating a claim that
Dr. Carlos J. Finlay was the first proponent of the theory that
yellow fever is caused by the Aedes Aegypti mosquito.

The Cubans have heard that, at a world medical meeting
scheduled to take place in Rome, in November 1954, the French
delegation is preparing to present a resolution to the effect
that a French doctor was the original discoverer of this medical
fact.

I understand that since 1939 you have been collecting data
on the work of Dr. Finlay, that you have made several trips to
Cuba and that you were actually responsible for rediscovering the
site of Camp Lazear where Major Walter Reed and his associates
worked out experiments which proved the veracity of Dr. Finlay's
theory. I believe that you stated, in an article which you wrote
in May 1948, that Dr. Finlay had been trying for nineteen years
to convince his medical colleagues that yellow fever was carried
by a mosquito.

Since you must possess authoritative knowledge of the accomplish-
ments of Dr. Finlay, you would undoubtedly be able to provide evi-
dence which would support the Cuban assertion. I mention this to
you in the hope that you may find it possible to do this in the
interests of relations between Cuba and the United States to which
you have already made great contributions.

I believe that you must be the same Dr. Hench whom I had the
privilege of meeting in Stockholm when you received the Nobel Prize.
If so, it is a double pleasure to write to you on this subject.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, Robert F. Woodward Robert F. Woodward
Acting Assistant Secretary
for Inter-American Affairs
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minnesota.
